Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content:
@jl777c  I mesaged miket but havent heard back... I dont think that is related. Although I think I have found an answer fixing it seems difficult... 
Theory is this, When you are the only staker this happens a lot, less so with more nodes.
The ram staker loads every 10 minutes from the wallet, but there is no way for it to clear a tx after its choses that I can see. So it can select one twice. Of course this means that the second time its chosen the block is invalid. 
Then when it disconnects tip, it removes the chosen tx from the wallet by force, with EraseTransaction (the same as I used in my wallet cleaner)
This means that the valid staked utxo now has been removed from the wallet and cannot be an input for the next tx seen.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: this also explains the null pwaleltin relay transactio0n crash

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: that was introduced after the ram staker

Author: axo777#1232
Content: Here is a cute presentation by some Hyperledger Sawtooth Lake devs about fish tracking.  The basic concepts there can be deployed in many sectors of our CC tools.  The Hyperledger devs will soon find the limitations of their platform choice.  Komodo has been wisely planned to avoid all of the pitfalls the others are bumping their heads on today.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-oxOas6cFXE

Author: axo777#1232
Content: Of course their promo stuff will never admit their challenges.  It is just so nice to have a platform that has been built from the ground up in such a way that the problems other ledgers will see do not enter the reality of Komodo blockchains.

Author: axo777#1232
Content: It appears that they are placing active RFID's on each fish caught.  While this is OK, it probably is not necessary.  All we really need is location information on the fishing vessel which is a GPS signal.  The skipper can issue a blanket barcode or QR code for the complete haul.  Sensors will transmit temperature and other data while on the fishing vessel. Then at port the fish will be processed and packed. At port individual package codes are generated at the palleting stage and uploaded to the blockchain.  Tracking continues for onward transportation by associating the smaller package Bar/QR Codes with the pallets (or equal) they are riding on or in until final delivery to the retail store. (This is in the case of fish, similar sequences apply for other products).  We can bribe the retail consumer with a few AXO's to scan and report their purchase or oonsumption of the fish with our smart phone "Report App" that signals to the Oracle that the supply chain is complete.  When the retail store receives the shipment payment can be triggered via a number of possible events all of which are reported by the oracle to the blockchain.  One possible event is crossing a "geofence" our user would set up on our platform.  (The geofence comes to us via an API from our GPS and cell network signal partner.

Content:
For multiple address's :
```#!/bin/bash
addresslist=(
"RTVti13NP4eeeZaCCmQxc2bnPdHxCJFP9x" 
"RXmXeQ8LfJK6Y1aTM97cRz9Gu5f6fmR3sg" 
"RGsQiArk5sTmjXZV9UzGMW5njyvtSnsTN8"
"RMwEpnaVe3cesWbMqqKYPPkaLcDkooTDgZ"
"RQVvzJ8gepCDVjhqCAc5Tia1kTmt8KDPL9"
"RFgzxZe2P4RWKx6E9QGPK3rx3TXeWxSqa8"
"RHq3JsvLxU45Z8ufYS6RsDpSG4wi6ucDev"
"RN2KsQGW36Ah4NorJDxLJp2xiYJJEzk9Y6"
"RF4HiVeuYpaznRPs7fkRAKKYqT5tuxQQTL"
"RG28QSnYFADBg1dAVkH1uPGYS6F8ioEUM2"
)

JSON='"{\"'
JSON2='\":100,\"'

for address in ${addresslist[@]}; do
     address="${address%\"}"
     address="${address#\"}"
     JSON+=$address
     JSON+=$JSON2
done
JSON="${JSON%???}}\""
echo $JSON ```
